facts.text: This is an appeal by special leave under Art. 136 of the Constitution of India against the Judgment of the Allahabad High Court confirming the conviction of the Appellant Raghubansh Lal under s. 218 of the Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: Kapur, J. This is an appeal by Special leave under Art. 136 of the Constitution of India against the Judgment of the Allahabad High Court companyfirming the companyviction of the Appellant Raghubansh Lal under s. 218 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Appellant Raghubansh Lal was a Patwari of village Arazi Mafi Pandai and a public servant.

anchor.surface_text: The offence for which the appellant was tried was, that being a Patwari of village Arazi Mafi Pandai and thus a public servant, he framed the khasra of 1358 F in respect of plots Nos. 170 and 74/1 of village Arazi Mafi Pandai,

facts.text: Appellant framed the khasra of 1358 F in respect of plots Nos. 170 and 74/1 which he knew to be incorrect with intent to cause or knowing to be likely that he would thereby cause an undue loss to Smt. Mahura Kunwar.

anchor.surface_text: which he knew to be incorrect with intent to cause or knowing to be likely that he would thereby cause an undue loss to Smt. Mahura Kunwar.

facts.text: Two brothers, Mahadeo and Sahdeo, who were members of a joint Hindu family owned certain plots of land.

anchor.surface_text: The facts out of which this appeal has arisen are these. Two brothers, Mahadeo and Sahdeo, who were members of a joint Hindu family owned certain plots of land.

facts.text: Mahadeo died leaving a widow Basera Kunwar, a son Damodar Pande and a daughter Mahura Kuer.

anchor.surface_text: Mahadeo died leaving a widow Basera Kunwar, a son Damodar Pande and a daughter Mahura Kuer.

facts.text: Sahdeo died leaving a widow Sundra Kuer.

anchor.surface_text: Sahdeo died leaving a widow Sundra Kuer.

facts.text: On the death of Damodar Pande, Ram Sewak Pande brought a suit against Smt. Basera Kunwar and Smt. Sundra Kuer for possession of zamindari property including sir and sayar left by Damodar Pande which was dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: On the death of Damodar Pande, one Ram Sewak Pande brought a suit against Smt. Basera Kunwar and Smt. Sundra Kuer for possession of zamindari property including sir and sayar left by Damodar Pande which was dismissed.

facts.text: On the death of Basera Kunwar, Adit Pande son of Ram Sewak and one Ganga Pande got their names mutated in regard to this property.

anchor.surface_text: On the death of Basera Kunwar, Adit Pande son of Ram Sewak and one Ganga Pande got their names mutated in regard to this property.

facts.text: Smt. Mahura Kuar brought a suit for possession of the estate left by Smt. Basera Kunwar against Adit Pande and Ganga Pande which was decreed on August 1, 1941.

anchor.surface_text: Smt. Mahura Kuar then brought a suit for possession of the estate left by Smt. Basera Kunwar against Adit Pande and Ganga Pande which was decreed on August 1, 1941.

facts.text: On May 31, 1943, Smt. Mahura Kuar obtained possession through Court of this estate which included the two plots Nos. 170 and 74/1.

anchor.surface_text: On May 31, 1943, Smt. Mahura Kuar obtained possession through Court of this estate which included the two plots Nos. 170 and 74/1.

facts.text: On February 25, 1950, Mahura Kuer made an application to the Sub-Divisional Magistrate for taking proceedings under s. 145 of the Criminal Procedure Code against Adit Pande and Ganga Pande.

anchor.surface_text: On February 25, 1950, Mahura Kuer made an application to the Sub-Divisional Magistrate for taking proceedings under s. 145 of the Criminal Procedure Code against Adit Pande and Ganga Pande.

facts.text: The Magistrate ordered the attachment of the land including the two plots Nos. 170 and 74/1, and possession of these two plots was given to Shubh Karan as sapurdar or custodian.

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate ordered the attachment of the land including the two plots Nos. 170 and 74/1, and it is alleged that possession of these two plots was given to Shubh Karan as sapurdar or custodian.

facts.text: The property remained under attachment from March 15, 1950, to December 18, 1950, which would comprise a part of 1357 F and a part of 1358 F.

anchor.surface_text: The property remained under attachment from March 15, 1950, to December 18, 1950, which would companyprise a part of 1357 F and a part of 1358 F.

facts.text: On December 18, 1950, the proceedings taken by the Magistrate ended in favour of Mahura Kuar with the finding that her possession had been established.

anchor.surface_text: On December 18, 1950, the proceedings taken by the Magistrate ended in favour of Mahura Kuar with the finding that her possession had been established.

facts.text: Adit Pande and Ganga Pande were restrained from interfering with the possession of Mahura Kuar and attachment was ordered to end and possession handed back to her.

anchor.surface_text: Adit Pande and Ganga Pande were restrained from interfering with the possession of the lady and it was ordered that the attachment should end and the possession of the plots of land in dispute be handed back to Smt. Mahura Kuer.

facts.text: Opposite party took revision to District Magistrate which was dismissed on March 28, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The opposite party took a revision to the District Magistrate which was dismissed on March 28, 1951,

facts.text: Actual possession was delivered in April, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: and it is alleged that actual possession was delivered in April, 1951.

facts.text: From December 1950 to April 1951, delivery of possession remained stayed under the District Magistrate's order.

anchor.surface_text: From December 1950 to April 1951, the delivery of possession remained stayed under the District Magistrates order.

facts.text: On July 31, 1951, Smt. Mahura Kuar filed complaint in the Court of the Judicial Magistrate at Ghazipur under s. 218 IPC against the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: On July 31, 1951, Smt. Mahura Kuar filed the present companyplaint in the Court of the Judicial Magistrate at Ghazipur under s. 218 of the Indian Penal Code against the present appellant

facts.text: Accused deliberately made wrong entries in regard to plots Nos. 170 and 74/1 and in remarks column entered name of Adit Pande as being in possession.

anchor.surface_text: in which after reciting the various relevant facts she alleged that the accused who was a Patwari of the village had deliberately made wrong entries in regard to the plots Nos. 170 and 74/1 and in the remarks companyumn had entered the name of Adit Pande as being in possession,

facts.text: Case committed to Court of Session.

anchor.surface_text: The cases was companymitted to the companyrt of Session where

facts.text: Prosecution witnesses: Smt. Mahura Kuer PW1, Gouri Shankar PW2, Naresh PW3.

anchor.surface_text: in support of the prosecution Smt. Mahura Kuer herself appeared as witness No. 1 and her case was supported by two other witnesses, namely, Gouri Shankar P.W. 2 and Naresh P.W. 3.

facts.text: Defence witnesses: Adit Pande DW1, Ram Swarup DW2.

anchor.surface_text: The accused produced in defence Adit Pande, D.W. 1 and Ram Swarup D.W. 2.

facts.text: Accused's plea: Knew from Shubh Karan that Mahura won s.145 case, but found possession on spot with Adit Pande, did not receive Magistrate order, Mahura not in actual possession.

anchor.surface_text: The accuseds plea in the Sessions Court was that he had companye to know from Shubh Karan Chowkidar that Smt. Mahura Kuar had won the case under s. 145 of the Criminal Procedure Code, but in spite of the order of the Magistrate he found the possession on the spot to be of Adit Pande, that he did number act according to the order of the Magistrate because he did number receive any such order and that he did number find Smt. Mahura Kuar in whose favour the order was passed by the Magistrate to be in actual possession.

facts.text: Trial court found accused made incorrect entries knowing them to be incorrect with intent to cause gain to Adit Pande and loss to Mahura Kuar, convicted and sentenced to 1 year RI and Rs.200 fine or 4 months RI default.

anchor.surface_text: The learned trial companyrt found that the accused had made incorrect entries knowing them to be incorrect with intent to cause gain to Adit Pande and loss to Smt. Mahura Kuar. He, therefore, companyvicted the accused and sentenced him to one years rigorous imprisonment and a fine of Rs. 200 or in default 4 months rigorous imprisonment.

facts.text: High Court confirmed trial court's decision.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court companyfirmed the trial companyrts decision

facts.text: High Court held delivery of possession to Mahura in April 1951 proved by statements of Mahura, Gauri Shankar, Naresh; Shubh Karan sowed crops; entries incorrect to injure Mahura.

anchor.surface_text: on the ground that the delivery of possession to the companyplainant Smt. Mahura Kuar was proved by the statements of the lady herself and of Gauri Shankar and Naresh Gadaria, who had supported the statement of Mahura Kuar and had deposed that Shubh Karan sapurdar had sown barley in one field and paddy in the other and that actual physical possession was delivered to her in April 1951. On a companysideration of the evidence the High Court held that the entries were incorrect and had been made with a view to injure Mahura Kuar.

facts.text: In remarks column for 1358 F, entry was 'qabiz badastur possession as before'.

anchor.surface_text: In the remarks companyumn - and this is shown by the order of companymitment - the entry of the years 1347 F and 1358 F was qabiz badastur  possession as before.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds prosecution failed to prove criminal intention under s.218 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances of the case it cannot be said that an offence under s. 218 has been companymitted by the appellant as in our opinion the prosecution has failed to prove the necessary criminal intention.

facts.text: Appeal allowed, conviction set aside, accused acquitted.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances, we would allow the appeal, set aside the order of companyviction and acquit the accused.

arguments.claim: Patwari must make entries in khasra in accordance with actual facts by inquiry from concerned persons and field inspection

anchor.surface_text: Rule 60 of the U.P. Land Records Manual deals with preparation of Khasras. The form of the khasra contains columns showing the name of the cultivator, the name of the sub-tenant or tenants and entries relating to crops etc. The rule requires that the entries shall be made in accordance with the actual facts and provides that the Patwari is responsible for all entries and he must satisfy himself of the facts by inquiry from the persons concerned as well as by field inspection and complete the khasra by April 30th.

arguments.claim: Courts below considered s.145 proceedings to find incorrect entries with intent to injure Mahura

anchor.surface_text: In coming to the finding of incorrectness of the entries in the khasra with intent to cause injury to Smt. Mahura Kuar, the Courts below have taken into consideration the proceedings under s. 145 of the Criminal Procedure Code. Although the finding of the Magistrate in those proceedings was in favour of Smt. Mahura Kuar, the land in dispute had been attached and had been given for cultivation to Shubhkaran Chowkidar,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ed the trial companyrts decision on the ground that the delivery of possession to the companyplainant Smt. Mahura Kuar was proved by the statements of

arguments.court_reasoning: Attachment meant no actual possession with Mahura till April 1951; sapurdar not examined

arguments.claim: Prosecution must prove (1) accused knowingly framed incorrect record (2) with intent or knowledge to cause loss/injury to public or Mahura

anchor.surface_text: For the purposes of this case, the prosecution had to prove -  1  that the accused knowingly framed the record in an incorrect manner and  2  that the accused did this with the intent to cause or with knowledge that he would thereby cause loss or injury to the public or to Smt. Mahura Kuar.

arguments.claim: Accused knew of litigation but insufficient for conviction; direct evidence of intent lacking, circumstantial evidence meagre

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the High Court found that the accused knew of the litigation between Mahura Kuar and Adit Pande and in spite of this he had made an incorrect entry. But in order to sustain the conviction it is not sufficient that the entries are incorrect, it is essential that the entry should have been made with the intention mentioned in s. 218 of the Indian Penal Code. Direct evidence proving the necessary intention is, in this case, lacking and the circumstantial evidence is too meagre to support any safe conclusion as to the intention with which the appellant made the entry complained of.

arguments.claim: Sapurdar Shubhkaran not examined creates doubt on prosecution case re possession

anchor.surface_text: His case was that the sapurdar, Shubhkaran, never got possession from Adit Pande. Shubhkaran was not a witness, may be for the reason already stated, and it was contended that in the absence of the testimony of Shubhkaran the case of the prosecution cannot be held to have been proved at least it is not free from doubt.

arguments.court_reasoning: Courts below considered circumstances and held for complainant on possession

arguments.claim: Incorrect entries for 1358F could not cause loss to complainant as s.145 already decided before entries made

anchor.surface_text: The question still remains whether the incorrect entries were made with the intent to cause or knowing it to be likely that the accused will thereby cause loss or injury to the complainant. It is difficult to see how any wrong entry in regard to the year 1358 F could cause any loss to the complainant. ... The entry could not have been intended to create evidence for being used against the complainant in the proceedings under s. 145 Criminal Procedure Code, because according to the evidence on the record the entries were made somewhere in March and this could not have helped Adit Pande, as the magistrate had already decided the proceedings under s. 145 Criminal Procedure Code in December 1950,

arguments.claim: Khasra entry for 1358F relevant for s.16 U.P. Zamindari Abolition Act to deem Adit as tenant

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Mathur founded his case also on s. 16 of the U.P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act,  U.P. Act I of 1951 , which provided that a person who was recorded as an occupant of the land for the year 1356 F and who, on the date mentioned in the section was in possession of the land, shall be deemed to be a hereditary tenant of the land.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ompanyplainant. In this case the intention has to be gathered from the act of the accused. The entry

arguments.court_reasoning: Entry complained of is for 1358F not 1356F, so not relevant for s.16

arguments.claim: Prosecution failed to prove necessary criminal intention under s.218

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances of the case it cannot be said that an offence under s. 218 has been committed by the appellant as in our opinion the prosecution has failed to prove the necessary criminal intention.

holdings.text: The accused knowingly framed the record in an incorrect manner.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the High Court found that the accused knew of the litigation between Mahura Kuar and Adit Pande and in spite of this he had made an incorrect entry. But in order to sustain the conviction it is not sufficient that the entries are incorrect,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts High Court's finding that accused knew of litigation yet made incorrect entry, satisfying first element of s.218 IPC.

holdings.text: The prosecution failed to prove that the accused framed the incorrect record with intent to cause or knowledge of likely loss or injury to Smt. Mahura Kuar.

anchor.surface_text: it is essential that the entry should have been made with the intention mentioned in s. 218 of the Indian Penal Code. Direct evidence proving the necessary intention is, in this case, lacking and the circumstantial evidence is too meagre to support any safe conclusion as to the intention with which the appellant made the entry complained of.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No direct evidence of intent; circumstantial evidence meagre; courts below erred in inferring intent from incorrectness alone.

holdings.text: Incorrect khasra entry for 1358 F could not cause loss or injury to complainant via s.145 CrPC proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: The question still remains whether the incorrect entries were made with the intent to cause or knowing it to be likely that the accused will thereby cause loss or injury to the complainant. It is difficult to see how any wrong entry in regard to the year 1358 F could cause any loss to the complainant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.145 proceedings decided in Dec 1950 before March 1951 entries; could not create evidence or affect result.

holdings.text: Khasra entry for 1358 F irrelevant for determining tenancy under s.16 U.P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act.

anchor.surface_text: But the entry complained of is not for the year 1356 F but for the year 1358 F, and this entry would not have been of any avail to Adit Pande for the purposes of s. 16 of the Zamindari Abolition Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.16 deems tenant based on 1356 F record and possession on vesting date; 1358 F entry does not apply.

holdings.text: No offence under s.218 IPC committed; prosecution failed to prove criminal intention.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances of the case it cannot be said that an offence under s. 218 has been committed by the appellant as in our opinion the prosecution has failed to prove the necessary criminal intention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: First element proved but second (mens rea) not; no possible injury from entry in given circumstances.

holdings.text: Appeal allowed; conviction and sentence set aside; appellant acquitted.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances, we would allow the appeal, set aside the order of conviction and acquit the accused.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Failure to prove all elements of s.218 IPC warrants acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances, we would allow the appeal, set aside the order of companyviction and acquit the accused.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed, order of conviction set aside, accused acquitted

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the High Court found that the accused knew of the litigation between Mahura Kuar and Adit Pande and in spite of this he had made an incorrect entry. But in order to sustain the conviction it is not sufficient that the entries are incorrect,
In these circumstances, we would allow the appeal, set aside the order of companyviction and acquit the accused.

anchor.surface_text: it is essential that the entry should have been made with the intention mentioned in s. 218 of the Indian Penal Code. Direct evidence proving the necessary intention is, in this case, lacking and the circumstantial evidence is too meagre to support any safe conclusion as to the intention with which the appellant made the entry complained of.

anchor.surface_text: The question still remains whether the incorrect entries were made with the intent to cause or knowing it to be likely that the accused will thereby cause loss or injury to the complainant. It is difficult to see how any wrong entry in regard to the year 1358 F could cause any loss to the complainant.
In these circumstances, we would allow the appeal, set aside the order of companyviction and acquit the accused.
But the entry complained of is not for the year 1356 F but for the year 1358 F, and this entry would not have been of any avail to Adit Pande for the purposes of s. 16 of the Zamindari Abolition Act.
In these circumstances, we would allow the appeal, set aside the order of companyviction and acquit the accused.
